awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Online Interactive Learning Platforms in STEM Education: A Study of Motivation and Engagement
awd_abstract_narration:
The low performance and retention of students in STEM classes are often attributed to lack of engagement and motivation.  Interactive online learning environments have the potential to engage students and motivate learning, and thus may contribute to increased performance and retention of students in STEM.   This project seeks to examine the efficacy of different configurations and design elements in a course platform for interactive, online learning. This platform, OneUp Learning, was previously developed by project team members.  The research study will measure the effects of the platform on the engagement and academic performance of students in computer science and data science courses.  It is expected that results of this research will lead to better design of online learning environments that support student motivation and contribute to improving undergraduate STEM education.


The research design of this project will be guided by Self Determination Theory, a well-validated psychological theory for understanding motivation and behavior change. The project will pursue three objectives: 1) conduct a series of empirical studies on the application of different elements of the OneUp platform in different learning contexts; 2) extend the OneUp platform by adding new elements to strengthen the platform's social dimension; and 3) develop instructional materials to help faculty use the OneUp platform to develop interactive modules for other courses at the participating institutions. To disseminate the results of these studies, the project team will solicit active community participation, through workshops, crowdsourcing, and related strategies. The project is a collaboration between two institutions, one of which is minority-serving. The partnership between institutions with different student populations will enable exploration of the impact of various platform features on diverse demographic groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to generate empirical evidence for the efficacy of using various game elements in gamified learning activities (LAs) to improve student motivation, engagement, and academic performance. Our work primarily focused on studying student motivation and engagement in gamified non-required LAs. The gamification designs included the use of single elements and combinations of elements. Twenty two empirical studies were conducted at 13 universities in different states, including 3 foreign universities. The universities included HBCUs and PWI (primarily white institutions). All studies were performed by using the educational gamification platform OneUp for gamifying out-of-class problem-solving practice in different STEM classes. The project also included extending of OneUp by adding unconventional gamification elements, such as virtual currency, goals, challenge duels and callouts, as well as the development of new course content for 13 gamified courses. The main outcomes of the project are as follows.

Impact of gamifying LAs with different game elements on student motivation, engagement, and achievement

A series of experimental studies were conducted using only badges, only virtual currency, and a combination of badges, virtual currency, leaderboards, and duels. For measuring student motivation, we used instruments based on the popular Self Determination Theory (IMI). For measuring student engagement we used the number of taken individual challenges (practice quizzes) and attempts (multiple taking of the same challenge), and for academic achievement, we used students' final course grades. All studies found a strong positive impact of the used gamification design on learners' engagement but did not find an increase of students' intrinsic motivation. The studies differed in their reports on the impact on student academic achievement: the study using only badges and those using combinations of game elements reported improved academic performance; two of the studies using only virtual currency reported slight improvement of students' course grades, while one didn't report any improvement.  

Comparing the impact of gamification of LAs in different contexts

The results from multiple case studies with the same gamification design but conducted in different contexts were aggregated to find the impact of factors like school type (e.g., HBCU vs. PWI), gender, or race on student engagement and academic performance. The findings include that school type determined a positive relationship between attempted challenges and course grades for PWI students but not for HBCU students, while for both HBCU and PWI students there was a significant effect of the distinct challenges taken on grades. The school type did not impact the relationship between psychological needs (as per IMI) and course grades; however, for men competence significantly predicted course grades. When split by race, the number of attempted challenges for European Americans predicted course grades, while the number of taken distinct challenges did not. Logically, engagement in the performance domain is a significant predictor of grades, which was significant for PWI students but not for HBCU students.

Using Expectancy-Value-Cost scale for measuring motivation

The most popular psychological theories used in gamification studies are Self Determination Theory and Flow Theory. However, they could not explain why in each study there was a group of students who didn't even login to OneUp to see if they would like the gamification features offered or not. Therefore, we proposed the use of Expectancy Value theory for evaluating student engagement in gamified LAs. We conducted two experimental studies for evaluating the predictive value of the Expectancy-Value-Cost measures: one at an HBCU and one at PWI. Both studies confirmed that a high cost of participating in LAs (e.g., effort and time required, other opportunities lost, emotional costs) resulted in low practicing attempts, reaffirming its demotivating role.

New gamification typology of learners

Most user models in gamification are based on user's gamer personality. However, the motivations driving individuals' learning behavior differ from their motivations when playing games. We proposed a context-specific typology, which groups learners based on their perception of two aspects associated with a learning activity: their type of motivation and perceived attainability of the activity goals (e.g., perceived ability for success and availability of mental or physical resources for achieving the goals).

Together, these outcomes contribute to a better understanding of the impact of gamifying learning activities on student engagement, motivation, and academic achievement, which will benefit researchers and practitioners in the field. Tangible outcomes include the creation of an open-source course gamification platform supporting a rich set of game elements, numerous scientific publications, and many students supported and trained.
